pullRequest.body:
This is a rewrite of the proof-construction in the `linear_combination` tactic to work around the issue https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/issues/4861.  Previously, a proof was built up as a `Term`, like
```
``(pf_add_c $p₁ $e₂)
```
The change is to instead build it up as an `Expr`, like `q(pf_add_c $p₁ $e₂)`.

I don't fully understand why, but this gives a 10x speedup on (at least some) large examples.  I have added one such example (which arose in real life as a `polyrith` output) to the test file.  There doesn't seem to be any big change on "normal-sized" examples -- it's possibly a little faster, but not much.

Trade-offs in this implementation:
- The tactic no longer solves equality goals in which the type is a metavariable.
- The default interpretation of coercions in coefficients of a `linear_combination` is now "deeper in", so coercions "on the outside" of a coefficient need to be written manually.  Example: for `a : Kˣ`, `x y : K`, and `h : x = y`, the coefficient `a⁻¹` in `linear_combination a⁻¹ * h` is now parsed as `(a:K)⁻¹`, so it is necessary to write `↑a⁻¹` to have the coercion happen outside the inversion. 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body: !bench

### PR summary [5483c674ec](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15570/commits/5483c674ecf8e95b622117ea1765df150217d0ff)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ LinearCombination`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/76f44562-30f5-4497-8215-37abafe84f76) for commit bfbe7eba56f42b912c67a5bd69c7cefe5b96a024.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/2d27fa77-6fd8-4877-aa3a-22f4ca34687e/to/76f44562-30f5-4497-8215-37abafe84f76) against commit 1f03949ae423ae9fb010318e73f8969e44288c92.

> * The tactic no longer solves equality goals in which the type is a metavariable.

Out of scope for this PR, but is a version of `synthInstanceQ` that creates a metavariable and askes lean to synthesize the instance later possible?

That presumably wouldn't work in the face of `assertInstancesCommute`, but would probably work in a fair amount of Qq code.

I haven't built all of mathlib yet, but over at #15599 I adapted the approach here to the original macro-based approach.

The macros aren't the slow part exactly, but instead it's mostly a matter of (1) double elaboration and (2) slowness in elaborating exponentiation. An unfortunate complexity with exponentiation is that in programming contexts you want `x ^ 2.1` with `x : Float` to end up with `2.1 : Float`, but if you use the default instances for monoids it would try to make it be `2.1 : Nat` and then end with an elaboration failure. What I did was force the exponentiation to elaborate in the math-friendly way by fully elaborating exponents ahead of time.

Backing this up with some numbers, while this PR uses 7500 heartbeats on the big example, the macro-based approach takes 7800.

It turns out re-using elaboration wasn't actually very important, and plus it made compiling mathlib fail. The most significant effect was in helping exponentiation elaborate quickly, bringing the time from 3.91s to 0.3s in the big example.
What makes elaboration of `^` in `linear_combination` different to elaboration of `^` elsewhere? Or is it slow everywhere?
It's slow everywhere unfortunately.
Closing in favour of #15599.
an aside: this pretty-printing/line-wrapping behavior of lean is pretty nuts, and perhaps worth opening an RFC about
Should this assert that no goals remain? I think we might have a combinator for "run `tac` on `mvar` and make it close the goal"
No, for example quite often one wants to run `linear_combination (norm := skip)`, precisely to see the remaining goals without closing them.
Perhaps I'm missing something; how do these unsolved goals end up back in the tactic list? Doesn't `setGoals` leave only the last one around, forcing the user to `recover`?

Ah, you're right: the tests don't contain an example in which simultaneously
- `mvars` contains more than one goal;
- `norm` does not close the first goal.

Here's an example like this:
```lean
example {a b c : ℤ} (h1 : a = 2) (h2 : b = c) : a + b = 2 + c := by
  linear_combination2 (norm := skip) h1 + h2
```
This indeed now produces an error "(kernel) declaration has metavariables '_example'".

Maybe you can tell me how to pick up the lost goal and add it back to the list -- I don't know how.

(By the way, the `linear_combination2` variant of the tactic is the only setting in which more than one goal would be generated, and as it happens, I've been planning to make a case for the deletion of that variant ....)
OK, 5483c674ecf8e95b622117ea1765df150217d0ff is to address this, not sure if it's the idiomatic way but it seems to work.

I just measured my caching experiment on this example, and it doesn't do too much: 3.91s on master, vs 2.58s with leanprover/lean4#4938. I didn't measure this PR's changes.

The problem is the caching only helps large expressions, but `elabTerm` is being called many many times here. Still, something along these lines might improve performance...

Is there an argument that the elaboration should happen all at once? That is, something like:
* build a `Syntax` with the equalities replaced with holes of the right type
* elaborate this expression
* parse the result with `Qq`, assemble a proof without invoking the elaborator

I think the current version on master is slow because it assembles the proof as `Syntax` too.

The current version on master is slow because of exponentiation elaboration relying on default instances (I mention this in the other comment). Fixing this makes the performance comparable to this Qq version.

The caching I was trying to do was to try to re-use these default instance problems as much as possible, but the caching has too small of a scope to be useful.

pullRequest.title: perf: work with `Expr`s rather than `Term`s in `linear_combination`

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - perf: eagerly elaborate leaf nodes in `linear_combination`

nodes.body:
I haven't built all of mathlib yet, but over at #15599 I adapted the approach here to the original macro-based approach.

The macros aren't the slow part exactly, but instead it's mostly a matter of (1) double elaboration and (2) slowness in elaborating exponentiation. An unfortunate complexity with exponentiation is that in programming contexts you want `x ^ 2.1` with `x : Float` to end up with `2.1 : Float`, but if you use the default instances for monoids it would try to make it be `2.1 : Nat` and then end with an elaboration failure. What I did was force the exponentiation to elaborate in the math-friendly way by fully elaborating exponents ahead of time.

Backing this up with some numbers, while this PR uses 7500 heartbeats on the big example, the macro-based approach takes 7800.

It turns out re-using elaboration wasn't actually very important, and plus it made compiling mathlib fail. The most significant effect was in helping exponentiation elaborate quickly, bringing the time from 3.91s to 0.3s in the big example.
What makes elaboration of `^` in `linear_combination` different to elaboration of `^` elsewhere? Or is it slow everywhere?
It's slow everywhere unfortunately.
Closing in favour of #15599.

source.title: feat(CategoryTheory/Sites): the Mayer-Vietoris long exact sequence in sheaf cohomology
